column4: hey guys, can anyone tell me if there's an easy way to *Nuke all traces of Grub from my system*?
unfortunately, there's no easy way to to do that with my Vista DVD
they've replaced XP's useful recovery console with some ridiculous graphical interface that can't find my installation
well, Ubuntu killed my Windows installation, so it's kind of forcing itself on me
what's the matter ?
- trying to install Ubuntu from my LIveCD took out my Vista installation and didn't work in itself
it probably just overwrote the boot loader, installing grub
you can either restore the windows bootloader using bootsect/bcdedit from the vista cd, or add the windows partition manually to grub using the linux live cd you're already using
of course if i were you, i wouldnt expect much help with the former in here ;)
if that's the issue, then it's a most trivial fix
just bear in mind that grub starts numbering disks from 0, whileas the devices are numbered starting from 1
for instance, disk /dev/hda1 (first disk on first ide channel) will be hd(0,0) for grub
I think I might have complicated the issue by attempting to install Ubuntu again and putting the bootloader on a different drive

once you're confident you know which disk holds the boot partition you're trying to boot, you can force that into grub by editing it at runtime, and then modifying its menu file once you've booted in the system
grub doesn't seem to want to let me have anything to do with it at runtime
the first thing it tells me about is  stage 1.5
so you can't even get INTO the grub menu, can you ?

you should boot from the live cd, figure out which disk holds the boot partition you want to boot (you can use "sudo fdisk -l" for that), and then restore grub, using something along the lines of (from the cmdline you get after starting "grub" from a terminal): root(hdx,y) and setup(hdx)

after that, grub should be rewritten to the boot sector of your disk, and you'll be able to boot into the grub menu - at which point you'll be able to manually edit entries (using "e" at grub boot menu), and boot into whatever partition you have setup
Ok, will attempt to give that a try - it's currently telling me it's probing devices to 'guess' bios drives which is reassuring...
it'd be nice if it could 'know' them
